Decidedly not an introductory book, this talks about analogies between number theory (you need some class field theory) and knot theory; so you need to be an expert in both fields to read it.
  • Peter Cromwell, Knots and Links. An intermediate level text which doesn't spend 50 pages on defining the fundamental group; this one actually proves the equivalence "two bridge" \(\iff\) "rational". Unfortunately, there is not much geometric topology.
  • Jessica Purcell, Hyperbolic Knot Theory. Modern book (2021) which is an introduction to knot theory tending towards geometry rather than towards knot invariants or topological theory. Technically minimal prerequisites beyond knowing some basic algebraic topology & some familiarity with manifolds (in the broadest possible sense). Introduction to knot theory and the parts of Thurston's hyperbolic programme not found in many `easy' books.

    This book is of the opinion that the primary way to work with 3-manifolds is via triangulations. This is certainly a point of view. Unfortunately regular readers will be aware that I don't share it, but many books struggle to have an opinion on anything (I will write more on this when I get around to finishing my essay on writing) and if you like combinatorial points of view and are a beginning graduate student to whom Thurston's notes look daunting this is probably a book you will like or find useful.

    The first few chapters follow Thurston's lecture notes fairly closely but are pitched at the level of an upper level undergraduate or masters student. The discussion of Dehn filling space is useful since it is not found elsewhere in this form except for the primary sources (I used it as a reference in the 2023 minicourse) but it has some issues, see below. Remaining parts of the book are broadly about the computation of invariants that can be found via triangulations.

  • Lois Kauffman, On Knots and Knots and Physics. I think in my 2023 notes I called OK "whimsical". Perhaps not as whimsical as Journey into Geometries, but still incredibly weird (not in a bad way); somehow K+P is even weirder. Certainly these are books with opinions.

    OK is a lot of ephemera of knots from quite a classical point of view (Conway and Alexander polynomials, Seifert surfaces, etc.). It was very useful in preparing the notes in 2023.

    K+P is basically a description of knot invariants from the point of view of scattering theory/QFT (I used to have a list of physics books, I should reintroduce that when I get time) plus around 400 pages of random physics-adjacent thoughts. The style reminds me of the cranks you read about who have invented a new way of writing large numbers and think that they will revolutionise mathematics, but in this case there is serious mathematics being presented. You don't need much physics but I found it helpful to already know a bit about scattering theory e.g. from the book by John R. Taylor (Dover).

  • Dale Rolfsen, Knots and Links. This book is primarily interested in homological invariants and fibrations. It was also useful to me but not as useful as Kauffman's On knots or Burde and Zieschang.
  • Gerhard Burde, Heiner Zieschang, Michael Heusener, Knots. This is a very thick knot theory handbook which I have found useful primarily for the expositions of braid theory and two-bridge links.
  • V.V. Prasolov and A.B. Sossinsky, Knots, Links, Braids and 3-Manifolds. Another 'triangulations, Dehn surgeries, and homology invariants' book, this one notable for being surprisingly readable in the Russian style. I complained above about knot theory books which spend the first half explaining carefully what a fundamental group is; somehow this is the opposite kind of book, which doesn't do any fundamental group work at all and immediately begins with the Jones polynomial and other more homological objects. There is also a very nice treatment of Dehn surgery theory.

  • Otto Forster, Lectures on Riemann surfaces. This is a very streamlined account of Riemann surfaces, from definitions to the Riemann-Roch theorem in a very short space of time. Quite algebraic which is an advantage to me but might be a disadvantage to an analyst, primarily interested in algebro-geometric problems.
  • Hershel M. Farkas and Irwin Kra, Riemann surfaces. A more analytic account which heads more in the direction of Kleinian groups and moduli theory. Very readable account of the uniformisation theory.
  • YoÃÑichi Imayoshi and Masahiko Taniguchi, An introduction to Teichm√ºller spaces. Elementary introduction to moduli spaces and mapping class groups in the complex context, more analytic than geometric; contains a very well-motivated introduction to the theory of quasiconformal mappings which is an advantage for going on to study moduli spaces of Kleinian groups, for instance as described in the later book co-authored by Matsuzaki and Taniguchi. One advantage that might not be immediately clear is that the theory is developed for surfaces in such a way that it can be adapted for marked surfaces (i.e. surfaces with points which may either be deleted or ramified). Also, this is the only book I know of which actually motivates clearly the point of quadratic differentials (see section 11.3).
  • Kari Astala, Tadeusz Iwaniec, and Gaven Martin, Elliptic PDEs and Qausiconformal Mappings in the Plane. I know nothing about PDEs, but the sections on quasiconformal mappings, holomorphic motions, etc. can be read without that background. Very useful reference particularly because of the large bibliography and lucid writing. Unfortunately it has a tendancy to reference entire books without page or section numbers (e.g. on p.296, "That two different elements share a fixed-point in a Kleinian group has algebraic implications [48]", where [48] is the 300 page book by Beardon on discrete groups -- admittedly it is fairly easy in this case to find the relevant section, but there are more annoying examples I can't find right now).

Algebraic geometry

Scheme theory.

  • Robin Hartshorne, Algebraic Geometry. This is the traditional introduction to scheme theory, and the first real textbook on the subject after Grothendieck invented it. It is not really an introduction to algebraic geometry: you need a very good background in varieties (i.e. you should really know everything in Chapter I from something like Harris or Shafarevich vol. 1 before you try properly to read this book). Chapters II and III are highly technical, and to see any geometry you need to do all the exercises. The final two chapters (on curves and surfaces respectively) are more geometric and rely only a little on the details of chapter III, so I would recommend skipping the bulk of III and going back to it once you understand the app
